title: Hilbert's 21st Problem: Riemann-Hilbert
content:
**Hilbert's 21st Problem (1900)**:

> Given singular points z₁,...,zₘ and a monodromy representation ρ, does there exist a Fuchsian differential equation with this monodromy?

**Status: SOLVED (with subtleties)**

- **Irreducible case**: YES (Plemelj 1908)
- **General case**: NO! (Bolibrukh 1989 counterexamples)

The problem connects complex analysis, ODEs, algebraic geometry, and representation theory.

title: Singular Points and Punctured Plane
content:
**Singular Points**:

The configuration space is ℂ with finitely many punctures {z₁, ..., zₘ}.

**Punctured Plane**:
$$X = \mathbb{C} \setminus \{z_1, \ldots, z_m\}$$

**Fundamental Group**:
$$\pi_1(X) \cong \text{Free group on } m-1 \text{ generators}$$

Loops around singular points generate the monodromy.

title: Monodromy Representations
content:
**Monodromy Representation**:

A group homomorphism:
$$\rho : \pi_1(\mathbb{C} \setminus \{z_1, \ldots, z_m\}) \to GL(n, \mathbb{C})$$

**Physical meaning**: How solutions transform when analytically continued around singular points.

**Irreducibility**: A representation is **irreducible** if it has no proper invariant subspaces.

**Key fact**: The Riemann-Hilbert problem has different answers for irreducible vs reducible representations!

title: Fuchsian Systems
content:
**Fuchsian System**:

A linear ODE system:
$$\frac{dY}{dz} = A(z) \cdot Y$$

where $A(z)$ has **simple poles** at singular points:
$$A(z) = \sum_i \frac{A_i}{z - z_i}$$

**Key properties**:
- Residue matrices Aᵢ at each singularity
- $\sum_i A_i = 0$ (from the point at infinity)
- Solutions have at most polynomial growth

title: Plemelj's Theorem (Irreducible Case)
content:
**Plemelj's Theorem (1908)**:

If the monodromy representation ρ is **irreducible**, then there EXISTS a Fuchsian system realizing it.

**Statement**:
$$\forall \rho \text{ irreducible}: \exists \text{ Fuchsian } F \text{ with monodromy } \rho$$

**This is the positive answer to Hilbert 21** for the irreducible case.

Plemelj originally claimed this for ALL representations, but that was incorrect...

title: Bolibrukh's Counterexamples (1989)
content:
**Bolibrukh's Discovery (1989)**:

There exist monodromy representations that CANNOT be realized by ANY Fuchsian system!

**First counterexample**:
- 4 singular points
- Dimension n = 3
- Reducible representation

**Theorem**: The general Riemann-Hilbert problem has a **negative answer**.

$$\exists \rho: \neg\exists \text{ Fuchsian } F \text{ with monodromy } \rho$$

This disproved Hilbert's original conjecture after 89 years!

title: Birkhoff's Theorem (Regular Singular)
content:
**Birkhoff's Theorem**:

If we allow **regular singular** systems (not just Fuchsian), then EVERY monodromy can be realized!

**Regular singular** = higher-order poles allowed, but solutions have at most polynomial growth.

**Fuchsian** ⊂ **Regular Singular**

$$\forall \rho: \exists \text{ regular singular system with monodromy } \rho$$

This shows the obstruction is specifically the **simple pole** (Fuchsian) constraint.

title: Complete Characterization
content:
**Characterization Theorem (Deligne-Bolibrukh)**:

A monodromy representation is Fuchsian-realizable if and only if certain **cohomological conditions** are satisfied.

**Obstruction lives in**:
- The splitting type of an associated vector bundle
- The Fuchs indices satisfy arithmetic conditions
- The Deligne-Malgrange category

**Formula**: Realizability ↔ vector bundle is trivial + Fuchs relations satisfied.

title: Riemann-Hilbert Correspondence
content:
**The Riemann-Hilbert Correspondence**:

Equivalence of derived categories:
$$D^b(\text{RegSingDMod}) \simeq D^b(\text{Perv})$$

**Connects**:
- Local systems (representations of π₁)
- Regular singular D-modules
- Regular singular connections on vector bundles
- Perverse sheaves

**Established by**: Kashiwara, Mebkhout, and others.

**Impact**: Cornerstone of the geometric Langlands program!

title: Problem Status: SOLVED (with subtleties)
content:
**Hilbert 21: SOLVED (nuanced answer)**

**Summary**:
| Case | Answer | Source |
|------|--------|--------|
| Irreducible ρ | **YES** | Plemelj 1908 |
| General ρ | **NO** | Bolibrukh 1989 |
| Regular singular | **YES** | Birkhoff |
| Complete criterion | **Known** | Deligne-Bolibrukh |

**The problem sparked**:
- Theory of linear ODEs with singularities
- Algebraic geometry (D-modules)
- Riemann-Hilbert correspondence
- Geometric Langlands program
